title: Politicians like former city coun. Ron Hayter can use their influence to promote a better experience for fans
text:
Report an error 
Every time we head toward an election, whether provincial or federal, the old memory bank kicks in and I remember former Premier Peter Lougheed’s understanding that sports fans and political junkies have much in common. 
“There’s so much politics in sport and so much sport in politics,” he once told me, “that they’re really the same game.” 
Former CFL receiver John Konihowski, for one, has mentioned a couple of times that when he learned of Lougheed’s words, they struck a resonating chord. 
Memory, for me, is tied to old friends such as Ron Hayter, the longtime Edmonton alderman now fighting the ravages of advanced age. 
And memory is the time that the Edmonton Trappers gave fans and broadcasters and major-league baseball-watchers plenty of reason to keep an eye on Edmonton. 
Hayter, in his role as head of what then was the Edmonton Boxing and Wrestling Commission, did his best in the difficult job of forcing matchmakers to concern themselves, first, with the health of boxers and, second, with the fans who bought tickets with a plan of watching close and fair competition. 
More than a month ago, KO Boxing promoter Mel Lubovic, with oversight from father Milan, put promising Alberta fighters Cam O’Connell, Paul MacKenzie and Ryan Ford into matches with Randy Lozano, Emile Arsenault and Ryan Kopas. All three bouts were competitive. 
On Friday, a Calgary promoter used O’Connell, Ford and Arsenault on a card against little-known opposition. Ford and O’Connell won by first-round knockouts against light-heavyweight and lightweight foes. Arsenault was stopped in the third round of his heavyweight clash. The evidence is clear that true competition was not part of any bout. 
But spectators paid the full price. 
What has that to with Hayter? Only that he used his influence with promoters here and in other communities to encourage fair entertainment for a fair price. 
At one point, he insisted an overseer should be appointed to check the records and other credentials of all combatants in the ring. I agreed it was necessary in those days. It’s still necessary. 
••• 
As for baseball, it’s fair to ask how many fans recognize the names Kyle Lohse, Mike Cuddyer, A.J. Hinch, Rusty Kuntz, Gary Pettis and so many more. 
All played in the majors after serving as Trappers. Cuddyer will be part of the New York Mets series with the Chicago Cubs. Hinch managed the Houston Astros, who bowed to Kansas City in one American League semifinal. 
Kuntz is a coach with the Kansas City Royals. Pettis, a brilliant outfielder, coached with Houston. 
In the last week or so, city representatives issued an invitation to citizens interested in keeping Telus Field open and active for top-level baseball. We’ll never get the Trappers or the Pacific Coast League back, but it’s my fervent hope that this community stays in organized baseball.
